stream_context.summary: Kaze spends most of the birthday stream iterating on Course 14: showcasing a new crayon-drawing mechanic, experimenting with HUD filtering, completely scrapping the “styrofoam mountains,” and prototyping a paper-spring object while brainstorming how to turn the snow section into a memorable ‘journey’ for Luigi’s lost crayon quest.

development_findings.summary: A new crayon-drawing feature lets the player literally ‘color in’ a star; when the outline is filled, the collectible spawns. Kaze still needs to add an SFX and polish multi-controller input handling.
development_findings.quote: Look at this cool thing I added off-stream… If you color the star, you get a star. How cool is that?

development_findings.summary: After testing texture filtering on the HUD, Kaze rejects the blur and keeps the original sharp pixel style for consistency across the game.
development_findings.quote: We don't want to make arbitrary changes like that… I think I prefer it like this over what I had before.

development_findings.summary: The current Styrofoam mountain set-piece is declared “terrible” and will be rebuilt; the area is now planned as a snow biome tied to Luigi’s crayon mission.
development_findings.quote: So the Styrofoam mountains… I have decided they're terrible and I want to redo them.

development_findings.summary: A paper-spring object is being modeled from scratch to act as a new platforming mechanic; Kaze struggles with the real-world folding geometry and is refining squash-and-stretch plus spring physics to feel predictable yet fun.
development_findings.quote: This is a paper spring… I will just start 3D modeling it from the bottom… These are great spring physics. They look realistic, but they're fudged enough to make this work.

development_findings.summary: He plans to generalize object-sliding and other helper functions so multiple objects can share clean code, reducing future re-work.
development_findings.quote: I want to work on making more general-purpose functions for a lot of these objects.

development_findings.summary: Star-collection screen is a placeholder; he wants a celebratory animation that avoids a garish ‘Cocomelon’ look.
development_findings.quote: What do you think we should add to it… I don't want it to end up looking like Cocomelon.

development_findings.summary: No 100-coin stars will exist; difficulty is being tuned for accessibility, with optional self-imposed challenges providing depth for advanced players.
development_findings.quote: Someone once told me that games being difficult is an accessibility issue… I make sure that people can play my games.

development_findings.summary: He embraces ‘schizophrenic’ level design—adding seemingly random but memorable set-pieces, citing Hazy Maze Cave as inspiration.
development_findings.quote: You kind of just need to be schizophrenic and make connections that don't exist in your levels to maximize on that concept.

development_findings.summary: Potential solutions for the crayon-return quest include invisible platforms revealed by drawing, breakable box barriers, button-triggered bridges, or snowflake particle cues.
development_findings.quote: What if you use the crayon to draw something on the floor to make progress? Oh, now we are going somewhere.

development_findings.summary: The Bit Pipe secret entrance will be moved for clearer visibility—possibly hidden behind the cliffs or inside a gift box that can be unwrapped.
development_findings.quote: Maybe we move it here so you can see it… There could be a gift with a ribbon that you open and the pipe is in it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze defines true difficulty as tasks that physically bar certain players; he prefers games be playable by everyone, with optional challenges for experts.
context_findings.quote: For me, true difficulty means some people can't play your game. I wouldn't even say Dark Souls is difficult; it just requires trial and error.

context_findings.summary: He argues large companies like Nintendo act on calculated legal strategy, not on single ‘taunting’ tweets, so his joking requests for rights are harmless.
context_findings.quote: Nintendo is not one meathead… They're not going to make a decision based on just one stupid joke tweet.

context_findings.summary: Birthday stream ambiance: Kaze mentions turning 29, Zeina brings chocolate milk and possibly a cake, and chat sends donations—showing community support.
context_findings.quote: It is indeed my birthday… Zayna made me a chocolate milk.

context_findings.summary: He sees social media platforms through a utility lens, dismissing BlueSky because of the ‘positive feedback loop’ problem.
context_findings.quote: BlueSky doesn't really exist yet. It's never going to exist.

context_findings.summary: Kaze’s creative ethos values sincerity and innovation over pandering trends; he criticizes content made just for ‘15-year-old viewers’ as ‘giga cringe.’
context_findings.quote: If you're being insincere, that's usually very cringe.

biobak.summary: Gave live feedback that the HUD looked blurry and donated in chat, prompting Kaze to re-evaluate filtering settings.
biobak.quote: Also someone said the HUD looks bad… Thank you, Biobak.

biobak.summary: Suggested color-coding the crayon after collection (‘make the crayon blue’), which Kaze immediately noted for implementation.
biobak.quote: The crayon should be blue. Oh, that is such a good idea.

zeina.summary: Provided off-stream personal support (bought birthday cake, made chocolate milk) and appeared briefly in chat; no direct development input this session.

key_stories.title: The Crayon Drawing Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: Kaze unveiled a mechanic where players literally draw on a pastel outline; filling it spawns a star. He still needs audio cues and polish, but it redefines interaction in Mario 64.
key_stories.challenge: Add a fresh, tactile mechanic that feels hand-made and fits the craft theme.
key_stories.process: Implemented drawing input, multi-controller handling and pastel shader; tested HUD feedback live.
key_stories.outcome: Working prototype demonstrated on stream; plans to add sound effects and color-change when Luigi reclaims the crayon.
key_stories.key_quote: This is what you've always wanted… If you color the star, you get a star.

key_stories.title: Taming the Paper Spring
key_stories.summary: Kaze fought Blender geometry and in-game physics to turn a folded paper spring into a reliable trampoline-style object.
key_stories.challenge: Modeling accurate zig-zag folds without mesh collision while achieving fun, predictable bounce in engine.
key_stories.process: Sketching folds on paper, iterative modeling, implementing squash-and-stretch, and tweaking damping values live.
key_stories.outcome: A ‘realistic but fudged’ spring now functions; further polish needed on bounce feathering and collision edge-cases.
key_stories.key_quote: These are great spring physics. They look realistic, but they're fudged enough to make this work.

key_stories.title: Redesigning the Snow Biome & Luigi’s Lost Crayon Quest
key_stories.summary: Unsatisfied with ‘styrofoam mountains,’ Kaze scraps the area and conceives a snowy cardboard village where Luigi’s missing crayon triggers a short but meaningful journey.
key_stories.challenge: Previous layout felt bland—player simply walked to the crayon and back.
key_stories.process: Brainstormed obstacles: breakable boxes, button-bridges, invisible platforms revealed by drawing; debated materials (cotton snow, foam-toothpick snowmen).
key_stories.outcome: No final geometry yet, but a clear design direction to make the trip feel like an adventure rather than a fetch-walk.
key_stories.key_quote: I want bringing the crayon back to be a challenge… How do we make this feel more like a journey?

open_questions.context: Prototype works but is silent; Kaze wants a satisfying sound and possibly visual polish.
questions: What style of sound effect are you envisioning for drawing and star completion?
Will the crayon change color contextually (e.g., blue after Luigi’s quest) across the game?

open_questions.context: Filtering was rejected today, but long-term aesthetic and readability goals remain undecided.
questions: Is the current HUD now locked, or will further tweaks happen?
Were there alternative styles prototyped off-stream?

open_questions.context: Bounce feels better but still snaps open and lacks feathering.
questions: What technical approach will you use to add easing without sacrificing performance?

open_questions.context: Kaze debated cotton, foam, marshmallow textures but hasn’t chosen.
questions: Which craft material best conveys snow within N64 limits?
Could graphics constraints lead to a stylized alternative (e.g., glitter confetti snow)?

open_questions.context: Idea surfaced to reveal paths only after drawing.
questions: How will collision behave before platforms are ‘painted’?

open_questions.context: Entrance will be moved; gift-box reveal proposed.
